qas.question: What type of cells do all animals have?
What is the extracellular matrix surrounding eukaryotic cells made of?
What is formed when the collagen and elastic glycoproteins surrounding eukaryotic cells are calcified?
How are cells held in place in plants and fungi?
What are the intercellular junctions unique to animal cells?

answers.text: tight junctions, gap junctions, and desmosomes

context: All animals have <a0_0>eukaryotic<a0_0/> cells, surrounded by a characteristic extracellular matrix composed of <a1_0>collagen and elastic glycoproteins<a1_0/>. This may be calcified to form structures like <a2_0>shells, bones, and spicules<a2_0/>. During development, it forms a relatively flexible framework upon which cells can move about and be reorganized, making complex structures possible. In contrast, other multicellular organisms, like plants and fungi, have cells held in place by <a3_0>cell walls<a3_0/>, and so develop by progressive growth. Also, unique to animal cells are the following intercellular junctions: <a4_0>tight junctions, gap junctions, and desmosomes<a4_0/>.
